discussion.content:
Secure Shell (SSH) for Linux-based machines
Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) for Windows-based machines ( A ) Is the correct answer

you can SSH into a linux server, I do it when SSH'ing into my AWS instances. 

Answer is A.

I also don't think SSH is the correct answer. The techie needs to access the Linux Desktop, but SSH only leads to the console.
Unless they're talking of port forwarding, which was actually never mentioned...

comments.content: I need to make a correction to the above: After doing some reading, I have realised that ssh in tunnel mode is the same as port forwarding, this makes A the correct answer. Follow this link for details: https://www.ssh.com/ssh/tunneling/example
Huge help, thanks!

discussion.content:
I think the answer should be B. SSH wouldn't allow you to see the desktop only a CLI. From the linux site "By default, Ubuntu comes with Remmina remote desktop client with support for VNC and RDP protocols. We will use it to access remote server."
My opinion answer should be B.

comments.content: RDP -> Windows. But the question is in Linux-based.

I signed up just to comment on this. You are flat out wrong. The question specifically is asking about being able to see the desktop. 

Go to AWS. Set up a linux instance. ANY linux instance. You can ssh to it but.....you can also get to the desktop via RDP. It's how I got familiar enough with linux before I dedicated a dual boot system and then finally made my laptop a linux machine full-time.

questions.question_text: A network technician wants to remotely and securely access the desktop of a Linux workstation. The desktop is running remote control software without encryption. Which of the following should the technician use to secure the connection?
A technician is required to install a new DOCSIS-based Internet connection. Which of the following medium types does this use?

discussion.content: RG-6 is often used for cable TV and cable modems.
DOCSIS Data over CABLE Service INterface SPecifications, well the name is self-explanatory. RG-6 used for CABLE modems makes it the only answer.
process of elimination , rest are not even related and cant be used

questions.answer_description:
On the first exhibit, the layout should be as follows

Access Point Name AP1 -

IP Address 192.168.1.3 -

Gateway 192.168.1.2 -

SSID corpnet -

SSID Broadcast yes -

Mode G -

Channel 1 -

Speed Auto -

Duplex Auto -

WPA -
Passphrase S3cr3t!

Exhibit 2 as follows -

Access Point Name AP2 -

IP Address 192.168.1.4 -

Gateway 192.168.1.2 -

SSID corpnet -

SSID Broadcast yes -

Mode G -

Channel 6 -

Speed Auto -

Duplex Auto -

WPA -
Passphrase S3cr3t!

Exhibit 3 as follows -

Access Point Name AP3 -

IP Address 192.168.1.5 -

Gateway 192.168.1.2 -

SSID corpnet -

SSID Broadcast yes -

Mode G -

Channel 11 -

Speed Auto -

Duplex Auto -

WPA -
Passphrase S3cr3t!

comments.content: I think this is the best solution. All the devices in the problem are on the same subnet. The problem doesn't say to create three subnets.
You say that gateway of switch and speed & Duplex are given, but I don't see that info given anywhere unless you select show answer lol
switch is not a GW (unless it's a multi-layer switch), so I think the GW address should be 192.168.1.1 on router (not listed)

discussion.content:
Guys. For the IP addresses...
The instructions specify that all access pointS (all of them) should support a max of 30 devices. You need a CIDR of /27. Since the gateway is given right below the switch (192.168.1.2), the IPs are AP1: 192.168.1.3, AP2: 192.168.1.4, and AP3: 192.168.1.5. The speed and Duplex are also given. Auto/Auto.

comments.content:
"For Security, WPA2 should be good since it supports TKIP" 
You are wrong on that answer.

 The Access Points should be configured to only support TKIP clients at a maximum speed:
Meaning it needs to be WPA which ONLY supports TKIP clients. Remember WPA2 deals with AES and we don't know whether is wpa2 personal or wpa2enterprise.

Is asking to

discussion.content:
Names (Probably whatever you want, I also called it as the picture for simplicity): AP1, AP2, AP3
Gateway: 192.168.1.2 to match the switch
SSID CorpNet, with broadcast enabled
Mode should be G if G and B are the only options, since B would just be slower on the same frequency. 
Channels should be 1 for AP1, 6 for AP2, 11 for AP3, to have the minimum amount of overlap in wireless signals.

For Security, WPA2 should be good since it supports TKIP. Not Enterprise since that would use 802.1x. The password should be "S3cr3t!" as mentioned.

As for the subnetting of IPs, all I can tell you is that the right subnets are /27, to support 32 devices in total (the 30 host devices + broadcast and network addresses). I'll let someone better at subnetting than me give the correct IP addresses for each AP since I don't want to give any wrong answers.

Based on the wording do the access point hold 30 devices each or 30 devices for all 3 combined. 

If its all 3 combined you could technically make 2 CIDR 29 and one 28 though i don't think that's what its looking for as you may have a gateway problem similar if you make 3 different subnets all connecting to gateway 192.168.1.1. 

so for the 3 AP use 192.168.1.2/3/4. cidr 27 CorpNet, yes to SSID broadcast. G, channels 1,6,11 auto speed/auto duplex. WPA2 and Enterprise uses AES. 

Then never work there again (or take credit) because A: bad password B: WPA2 isn't secure enough anymore: C: 30 devices only you will have DHCP scope exhaustion before the end of the day.
WPA or WPA2 ?
why dont they use wpa2?

comments.content: "The subnet the Access Points and switch are on should only support 30 devices maximum" means 3 APs and switch on same subnet, so your IPs is not correct.

discussion.content: Why is speed being set to "auto?" The question explicitly says "the access points should be configured to ONLY support TKIP (AES) clients at a MAXIMUM speed. Setting to auto allows devices to connect at lower speeds. Any explanation?

comments.content: If you look closely that says wired.. It looks like that is connection from AP to the switch , which probably matches the switch settings...

discussion.content: This is my best guess. We need a /27 for 30 devices. Its not clear form the wording if they all should be on one subnet or each subnet should have 30 devices. You could group them all together like Breakoff or split them up. .0-.31 (gateway=.1, switch=.2), .32-.63 (ap1=.33), .64-.95 (ap2=.65), and .96-.127 (ap3=.97)

comments.content: The text-based answers are the correct ones. The images in the solution seem wrong.

discussion.content: why the answers are different in the given picture
why the answers doesn't match the exhibits ?? which one is correct ? any one can help plz

questions.answer_description: On PC3, change the subnet mask to 255.255.255.0. When it is set to 255.255.255.128, then the PC with a .129 address will not be on the same subnet as the default gateway which is .1 On PC4, change the default gateway to 10.0.2.1. It has been incorrectly set as 10.1.2.1.

discussion.content: ipconfig gives you the setting on that device, the problem is that some pcs cant see the servers so shouldnt you ping the servers from each machine to make sure you can rather than check the settings have updated on each machine?
Doesn't the question also to verify settings, using command line black box. So, use command: ipconfig /all
is the answer correct?

comments.content: Looks to be!

questions.question_text: A small business utilizes a SOHO router and wishes to secure its existing wireless infrastructure. The business has fewer than ten devices, which are a mixture of old and new machines. Due to the varying ages of the machines, the latest wireless encryption methods may not be supported on all devices. Which of the following would be the MOST cost-effective method to add a layer of security while allowing all machines to connect?

discussion.content: CHANGE THE ANSWER. Do the people making these questions even know how to read? Some devices that don't support modern encryption? And the answer is WPA-2? Are you kidding me? This website's reputation has gone down the gutter as well as its authenticity. You can not prepare for a test with this website. The correct answer is MAC filtering since legacy devices do not always support 802.1X or WPA/WPA2 Enterprise networks with AAA. MAC filtering is arbitrary security for a small network and can be attacked easily but atleast its a another layer of security.

comments.content: I disagree. WAP2 also has a personal mode where legacy should be able to connect. MAC filtering can be bypassed with spoofing.
WPA2 is actually supported across many legacy devices. Iphone 3G even supports WPA2

WPA2 because WPA2 is backwards compatible with legacy equipment.

https://www.howtogeek.com/204697/wi-fi-security-should-you-use-wpa2-aes-wpa2-tkip-or-both/
And that's how CompTIA tricks people my friend. You have to know how to read their questions, their goal is to make you choose the wrong answer.
True, but I believe the wording of the question is pointing to the use of MAC filtering.
the latest wireless encryption methods may not be supported on all devices. So its not WPA2. I agree with nepa its MAC filtering

Fewer than ten devices... so MAC filtering. what i assume is that they already have WPA or whatever fits the situation for the wireless security. what they want is to improve it. but we cannot put the latest wireless encryption method. and the office has less than 10 devices. MAC filtering will do the job.

Disregard, I re-read this question multiple times. Although MAC filtering is what a normal person would do, the question is in fact asking for encryption. Given WPA2 can be backward compatible with TKIP, it is a viable option.
WPA2 is not the answer to this question. At least not in the format this question is currently presented. WPA2 doesn't make sense....at all actually
You make these comments often, and this is another instance of you being wrong, the 5th I've seen so far. The answer is WPA2.
It is just a layer of cost effective security not hardening the network access. So i guess WPA2 makes more sense.

Oh no not again. I will change my answer to WPA2 because WPA2 is backward compatible to wireless legacy devices. Also, WPA2 has an encryption that uses either of 64 or 128 bit. Unlike Mac Filtering it uses only 48 bit that can be easily hacked through brute force attack.

discussion.content:
Hint 1: Less than 10 devices
Hint 2: Add a layer of security
Hence, the question is askin for second layer of security, in addition to WPA/WPA2 and that will be "MAC Filtering". 
Cheers!

comments.content: I was wrong. I sincerely apologize. Answer is A. WPA2.

discussion.content: The answer isn't A. This network has a mixture of old and new machines: Some of the machines don't support WPA2.
I think that MAC filtering may be the only viable solution since the question does explicitly state that not all machines may support the latest WiFi security standards.

WPA2 builds on its predecessor, WPA, and is specifically designed to meet the most demanding enterprise security needs. ... Furthermore, because WPA2 is backwards- compatible with WPA, organizations that have already implemented the WPA standard can migrate to WPA2 at their own pace.

Sometimes I filtered my nieces and nephews for using the internet and for fun and out of curiosity. Haha. This won't take time to block them. So I believe Mac Filtering is the answer since it has less than 10 devices. :)

comments.content: Oh no not again. I will change my answer to WPA2 because WPA2 is backward compatible to wireless legacy devices. Also, WPA2 has an encryption that uses either of 64 or 128 bit. Unlike Mac Filtering it uses only 48 bit that can be easily hacked through brute force attack.
